apis.api_description: Search for the matching apartment according to the number of bedrooms, price, floor, and whether or not the user needs an elevator

need_room.description: Number of bedrooms required. The default is 1

need_price.description: Deposit price acceptable to the user, value +yuan, the default "500 yuan"

need_folor.description: Which floor does the user want to live on? Default is "first floor"

is_elevator.description: Whether an elevator is required. Enumeration type, [Yes, No]. Default is "Yes"

is_find.description: Whether a suitable apartment can be found, enumeration type, [can be found, cannot be found]

apartment_message.description: Apartment information sheet. If not, there is no suitable apartment.

apartment_position.description: Location, such as "Chongqing Guanyinqiao Wuyue International Apartment"

apartment_cool.description: Availability of air conditioning, enumeration type, [Yes, No]

apartment_refrigerator.description: Availability of refrigerator, enumeration type, [Yes, No]

apis.api_description: Determine whether the user has successfully rented the apartment

is_money.description: Whether a deposit has been paid. Enumeration type, [Yes, No]. The default is "No"

is_protocol.description: Whether an occupancy agreement has been signed. Enumeration type, [Yes, No]. The default is "No"

is_apart.description: Whether the apartment has been rented. Enumeration type, [successfully rented, unsuccessfully rented]

workflow.text: The process starts with searching for apartments based on the user's specific needs, such as the number of bedrooms, price range, floor preference, and whether an elevator is desired. If no matching apartments are available, the user is informed and asked if they wish to modify their criteria. If they choose not to, they are apologized to for the lack of suitable apartments. However, if an apartment is available and the user is informed but not satisfied, they can choose either to view the apartment or inquire about other apartments. Should they wish to know about other options, the search restarts. If the user is satisfied with the apartment details, they decide whether to rent it immediately or view it first. If they opt to rent, the process checks if the rental is successful; if not, it may be due to issues like an unpaid deposit. In such a case, the user is informed about the failure and the possible reasons. If the user wants to view the apartment first, they are informed that the viewing process is being confirmed, indicating a wait time before the next steps can be taken. This flow ensures users are guided through their apartment search, offering options to adjust preferences, view apartments, or proceed with rental based on their satisfaction and the availability of suitable options.
workflow.code:
start: Start
    Search for apartments
    ask_for_specific_needs: Subgoal: ask for specific needs
        Description: inquire the user about the number of bedrooms, price, floor, elevator demand, or other needs.
        Call searchApartment to find matching apartments, and check the availability of matching apartments based on the returned is_find
        if Apartment is not available then
            inform_user_to_modify_info: Subgoal: inform the user to modify the information
                Description: inform the user that no apartment meets the given criteria, and ask if the user is willing to adjust the apartment criteria
                if Yes then
                    goto ask_for_specific_needs
                else
                    apologize_to_user: Subgoal: apologize to the user
                        Description: tell the user there is no suitable apartment and apologize to the user
                endif
        else
            inform_about_flat: Subgoal: inform about the flat and get opinions.
                Description: inform the user about the apartment according to the returned apartment_message and ask if the user is satisfied with the apartment
                if User is not satisfied then
                    ask_desire_to_see: Ask if the user would like to see the apartment before making a decision
                    if Desire to see then
                        confirm_view_process: The user needs to wait a moment, and the apartment viewing process is being confirmed
                    else
                        ask_about_other_apartments: Ask if the user wants to know about other apartments
                        if User wants to know then
                            goto ask_for_specific_needs
                        else
                            goto apologize_to_user
                        endif
                    endif
                else
                    ask_rent_or_look: Ask if the user rents the apartment now or takes a look first
                    if Rent Now then
                        check_if_flat_rented: Subgoal: check if the flat is rented.
                            Description: call apartmentSigning, and check if the lease is successful based on the returned is_apart
                            if Apartment rental succeeded then
                                notify_rental_success: Notify the user that the apartment is successfully rented
                            else
                                ask_for_deposit: Subgoal: let the user make a deposit.
                                    Description: inform the user that the apartment rental has failed, possibly due to the unpaid deposit or the unsigned occupancy agreement
                            endif
                    else
                        goto confirm_view_process
                    endif
                endif
        endif

：

workflow.summary: Users search for apartments by criteria (bedrooms, price, floor, elevator). If no matches are found they can modify their search or end the process; if matches exist they can view details, request other options (restarting the search), view the unit before deciding, or attempt to rent immediately. Successful rental proceeds; failed rental returns an explanation (e.g., unpaid deposit). Viewing requests are confirmed and introduce a wait before the next steps.

scenario: Make an appointment to view a home

apis.api_description: Get room information and salesman information

room_num.description: Room number being queried, zip code + "-" + room number, such as "400000-012893"

cell_name.description: Community name, such as "Phoenix City", and "Mountain Xianju", recording the room number being queried simply

floor.description: Floor number, such as "B1", "B5", and "13". Only the queried room number can be written

room_info_dict.description: Housing information, empty means not found

apis.api_description: Determine the viewing time

room_num.description: House number, zip code + "-" + room number, such as "400000-012893"

time_list.description: List of expected house viewing times. If not written, the nearest feasible time will be recommended

items.description: Time, format: day+hour+minute. such as "17th 12:28", and "31st 11:00"

observable_time.description: Available viewing times, given by the system

items.description: Time, format: day+hour+minute. such as "17th 12:28", and "31st 11:00"

workflow.text: The flowchart describes a process that begins when someone wants to view an apartment. If the user hasn't found a satisfactory flat, they search for an apartment, schedule a viewing, and proceed through the flow. If they have a preferred apartment, the room information is verified through a call to 'getRoomInfo' to ensure the details are correct and the room code isn't empty. If there's no desired room number or the parameters are empty, the search process restarts. Upon confirming the room number, the next step is to confirm viewing times with 'fixTime'. If no viewing times are available, the user is asked to either reschedule, look at another apartment, or wait to view the apartment later. If a suitable viewing time is found, the user is asked to provide their viewing time and phone number, ensuring they arrive at the community gate on time, where a salesman will meet them. This process ensures both the verification of apartment details and the scheduling of a viewing, facilitating a smooth experience for potential renters.
workflow.code:
Start:
    View an apartment
    Ask if the user already has a satisfied flat?
    if answer is NO:
        The user conducts an apartment search and then schedules a viewing
        goto Start
    else if answer is Yes:
        Subgoal: verify the room information
        call getRoomInfo to verify and get room information
        if room_code is empty or no desired room number:
            The user conducts an apartment search and then schedules a viewing
            goto Start
        else:
            Subgoal: confirm viewing times
            call fixTime to confirm the time
            if observable_time is empty:
                Subgoal: ask the user to reselect
                Inform the user: no viewing time available
                Ask the user to: Reschedule, View other apartments, or Wait for another time
                if Reschedule:
                    goto Subgoal: confirm viewing times
                else if View other apartments:
                    goto Start
                else if Wait for another time:
                    The user should make a call when arriving
            else:
                Subgoal: let the user provide viewing times
                Based on observable_time, fix the time with user
                Collect parameters: go_look_time, user_phone
                Inform the user: Come to the community gate in time, the salesman will wait
                If necessary, contact the salesman through salesman_phone

：
flowchart TD

RP001--NO-->RP002[The user conducts an apartment search and then schedules a viewing.]
RP001--Yes-->RP003>Subgoal: verify the room information.
Description: call getRoomInfo to verify and get room information. And check whether the returned room_code is empty.
If not, confirm the room number to the user based on the returned room_code.]
RP003--Parameter empty or no room number desired-->RP002
RP003--Room number has been confirmed-->RP004>Subgoal: confirm viewing times.
Description: call fixTime to confirm the time and check if the returned observable_time is empty?]
RP004--Value is empty-->RP005[Subgoal: ask the user to reselect.
Tell the user that there is no viewing time available, and require the user to reschedule, look at another house, or wait for another time to view the apartment.]
RP005--Reschedule-->RP004
RP005--View other apartments-->RP001
RP005--Wait for another time-->RP006[The user should make a call when arriving.]
RP004--Value is not empty-->RP007[Subgoal:  let the user provide viewing times.
Description: based on the returned observable_time, fix the time to the user and collect the parameters: go_look_time, user_phone.
The user is demanded to come to the gate of the community in time. The salesman will wait at the gate.
If necessary, the user can contact the salesman through salesman_phone.]

The auxiliary parameter information in the workflow is as follows:

"user_phone": "The user\"s phone number, 13 digits"
workflow.summary: When someone wants to view an apartment the process either starts with searching for listings or, if they already have a preferred unit, verifying its details via getRoomInfo. If the room number or parameters are missing, the search restarts. Once the room is confirmed, available viewing slots are checked with fixTime; if none are available the user can reschedule, view a different apartment, or wait. When a suitable time is found the user provides their viewing time and phone number and is instructed to arrive at the community gate on time, where a salesman will meet them. The workflow ensures apartment details are validated and a viewing is scheduled for prospective renters.

apis.api_description: Query the user's identity

person_nums.description: Mobile phone number, composed of numbers, such as "13223180476"

is_service.description: Apartment resident or not, enumeration type, [yes, no]

is_fee.description: The fee sheet for the user, is empty if the user is not a resident of the apartment or if the fee has already been paid

room_code.description: Room number, the user may have multiple rooms, in the format of "2 numbers +0+3 numbers ", such as "140028"

apis.api_description: Payment progress inquiry

person_phones.description: Mobile phone number, consisting of digits, such as "13302783127"

is_empty.description: Whether the fee has been paid, enumeration type, [paid, unpaid]

whone_amount.description: The fee that the user needs to pay, e.g. "322 yuan"

workflow.text: The flowchart describes a process for apartment fee payment which begins with determining the user's identity by asking for their phone number. If the user is not recognized as a resident, they are given a chance to provide their phone number again or exit the process. If identified as a resident, they are informed about their fee and asked if they want to pay now or later. Choosing to pay now moves the process to check if the fee has been fully paid, with reminders sent if the payment is incomplete. If the fee is fully paid, or if the user chooses to pay later, they are advised to complete payment as soon as possible, and the process ends with a farewell to the user. This summary encapsulates the user journey from identification through to payment completion, emphasizing the steps taken to ensure the user is a resident and the options provided for fee payment.
workflow.code:
start: Start
  Apartment fee payment? -> yes -> identify_user
  
identify_user: Current goal: Determine user identity
  Description: Ask for the user's phone number and call identityChecks to query the user's identity. Determine whether the user is a resident of the apartment based on the returned is_service.
  Resident of the apartment? -> yes -> ask_payment_now
  Resident of the apartment? -> no -> re_provide_phone
  
re_provide_phone: Current goal: Let the user re-provide the phone number
  Description: Inform the user that we have checked his/her identity through the mobile number, finding out that the user does not live in this apartment. Ask if the user would like to re-provide the mobile number so that we can check again for him/her.
  Provide the mobile number again? -> yes -> identify_user
  Provide the mobile number again? -> no -> say_goodbye
  
say_goodbye: Current goal: Say goodbye to the user
  Description: Inform the user that we only serve the residents of the apartment, and say goodbye to the user
  
ask_payment_now: Current goal: Ask if the user wants to pay for the apartment now
  Description: Inform the user of the fee to be paid based on the returned is_fee, and ask if the user wants to pay now or later.
  Pay now? -> yes -> check_payment_status
  Pay now? -> no -> remind_pay_early

remind_pay_early: Current goal: Remind the user to pay as early as possible
  Description: Inform the user that he/she can pay later. At the same time, the user is advised to pay the fee as early as possible
  
check_payment_status: Current goal: Determine whether the fee has been paid
  Description: The user can click on the logistics fee on Gulfstream Apartments' public account and then pay. Call paymentFees to query the payment progress. Judge whether the fee has been paid or not paid based on the returned is_empty.
  Fee paid? -> yes -> inform_paid
  Fee paid? -> no -> remind_to_pay
  
inform_paid: Inform the user that the fee has been paid in full, and say goodbye to the user

remind_to_pay: Current goal: Remind the user to pay
  Description: Tell the user that the fee has not been paid in full. Inform the amount of unpaid fees based on returned whone_amoun, and remind the user to pay as soon as possible.

workflow.summary: The workflow verifies a user’s identity by phone number to confirm residency, informs them of their apartment fee, offers options to pay now or later, handles payment attempts (including reminders for incomplete payments), and concludes by advising prompt payment and saying farewell.

apis.api_description: Query the identity information of the user

person_nums.description: Mobile phone number, composed of numbers, such as "13620517842"

is_person.description: Whether the user's identity information can be found, enumeration type, [yes, no]

apis.api_description: Billing Inquiry, the completed payment of the apartment fee, can be found in the bill

person_phone.description: Mobile phone number, composed of numbers, such as "13620517842"

person_date.description: The billing date to be queried, year + month + day, e.g. "February 21, 2050"

is_find.description: Whether the billing information can be found, enumeration type, [can be found, cannot be found]

is_message.description: The billing information form, is blank if the apartment has not been paid

workflow.text: The process begins with an inquiry into an apartment fee bill, aiming first to confirm the user's identity by asking for their phone number. This step involves a procedure called confirmationIdentity to verify the user's details. If the user's information is successfully identified, the process advances to determine if the billing information for a specified date can be retrieved. Should the billing information be available, the user is notified of their billing details. However, if the billing data cannot be found, perhaps due to an unpaid apartment fee, the user is prompted to decide whether they want to try another date. Should the user's information not be found initially, indicating they might not reside in the apartment or have provided an incorrect phone number, they are asked if they wish to supply a different phone number. If the user agrees to provide another number, the identification process is attempted again. Conversely, if the user decides against providing a new number or if billing information remains undiscoverable even after changing the date, the process concludes by notifying the user that the inquiry cannot be completed. This flowchart outlines a straightforward yet detailed procedure for handling apartment fee bill inquiries, emphasizing identity confirmation and the retrieval of specific billing information.
workflow.code:
start:
    call confirmationIdentity
    if is_person then
        goto confirmBillingInformation
    else
        goto confirmIdentityFailed

confirmIdentityFailed:
    inform user identity not found
    ask user to change phone
    if willing to change phone then
        goto start
    else
        goto endInquiry

confirmBillingInformation:
    ask for billing date
    call billingInquiry
    if is_find then
        goto billingInformationFound
    else
        goto billingInformationNotFound

billingInformationFound:
    inform user of billing info
    goto end

billingInformationNotFound:
    inform user bill not found
    ask if change date
    if wants to change date then
        goto confirmBillingInformation
    else
        goto endInquiry

endInquiry:
    inform user can't conduct inquiry
    end

end:
    // Process ends
workflow.flowchart:
：
flowchart TD
DM000(Start)--Apartment fee bill inquiry-->DM001>Current goal: Confirm the user's identity
Description: Ask for the user's phone number.
Call confirmationIdentity to confirm the user information
and determine whether the information can be found based on the returned is_person]
DM001--Information can be found-->DM004>Current goal: Determine if billing information can be found
Description: Ask the user for the date they want to check the bill.
Call billingInquiry and determine
whether the corresponding billing information can be found based on the returned is_find]
DM004--Billing information can be found-->DM006[Notify the user of the corresponding billing information based on returned is_message]
DM004--Billing information can not be found-->DM005[Current goal: Ask if the user wants to change the date
Description: Inform the user that the billing information could not be found.
The reason may be that the user did not pay the apartment fee on that date.
Ask the user if they want to change the date]
DM005--Change the date-->DM004
DM005--Do not change the date-->DM003
DM001--Information can not be found-->DM002[Current goal: Inquire if the user wants to change the phone number
Description: Inform the user that his/her identity could not be found.
That means the user is not a resident of this apartment.
The phone number he/she provided should be incorrect.
Ask the user if he/she is willing to provide the phone number again]
DM002--Willing to provide again-->DM001
DM002--Unwilling to provide again-->DM003[Notify the user that we are unable to conduct the inquiry]
workflow.summary: This workflow handles apartment fee inquiries by first confirming the user’s identity via phone number. If identity is verified, it attempts to retrieve billing information for a specified date and either presents the details or offers the option to try another date. If identity cannot be confirmed, the user is asked whether to provide a different phone number; if they decline or billing remains unavailable, the inquiry is terminated with a failure notification.

apis.api_description: Verify the moving fee

start_position.description: Start position, for example, "Fuxin Apartment, Guanyinqiao, Chongqing"

end_position.description: End position, for example, "Chongqing Jiefangbei Starlight Times Apartment"

moving_fee.description: Moving fee, value + yuan, such as "55 yuan"

apis.api_description: Verify if moving time is feasible

moving_time.description: Moving time, year + month + day, e.g. "March 16, 2025"

is_moving.description: Whether moving time is feasible, enumeration type, [feasible, not feasible]

workflow.text: The flowchart describes a process for booking a moving service, beginning with asking the customer if the move is within the same city. If yes, the customer is then asked if they accept the moving fee, which is determined after the moving information (origin and destination) is collected and the fee is calculated. If the customer accepts the fee, they are asked about their preferred moving time. If this time is feasible, the service is confirmed for that time. However, if the move is not within the same city, the customer is informed that only same-city services are provided, and they are asked if they want to change their request to fit this criterion. If they do not wish to change or do not accept the moving fee, the process ends. If the preferred moving time is not feasible, the customer is asked to choose another time. This process ensures that the service is efficiently booked according to the customer's needs and the company's capabilities, concluding with either a scheduled move or informing the customer if their needs cannot be met.
workflow.code:
start:
    Reservation of moving service
    Ask if destination is in the same city
    if (same city) then
        Ask user to accept moving fee
        if (accepts moving fee) then
            Inquire moving time
            if (moving time is feasible) then
                Inform service will be carried at the desired time
            else
                Ask to choose moving time again
                goto Inquire moving time
            endif
        else
            Say goodbye to the user
        endif
    else
        Ask if changes are required
        if (need to change) then
            Ask user to accept moving fee
            if (accepts moving fee) then
                Inquire moving time
                if (moving time is feasible) then
                    Inform service will be carried at the desired time
                else
                    Ask to choose moving time again
                    goto Inquire moving time
                endif
            else
                Say goodbye to the user
            endif
        else
            Say goodbye to the user
        endif
    endif
end
workflow.flowchart:
：
flowchart TD
SO000(Start)--Reservation of moving service-->SO001[Subgoal: Ask the user if the destination is in the same city
Description: Inform that if the origin and destination of the move are in the same city,
it is a same-city move, ask the user whether it belongs to.]
SO001--Yes-->SO003>Subgoal: Inquire the user whether he/she accepts the moving fee.
Description: Ask the user for moving information, including:
the origin and destination of the move,
call receiveMoveInfo to verify the moving fee,
and inform the user of the moving fee based on the returned moving_fee,
ask whether it can be accepted] 
SO001--NO-->SO002[Subgoal: Ask if changes are required
Description: Let the user know that only same-city moving service is provided,
and inquire whether the user needs to change to it]
SO002--Need to change-->SO003
SO002--Do not need to change-->SO004[Say goodbye to the user]
SO003--Accept moving fee-->SO006>Subgoal: Determine whether moving time is acceptable or not
Description: Inquire the user of the desired moving time,
call addPackingFee, judge whether the moving time is feasible based on the returned is_moving]

SO006--Moving time is feasible-->SO005[Inform the user that the moving service will be carried out at the corresponding time]
SO006--Moving time is not feasible-->SO007[Subgoal: Ask the user to choose the moving time again
Description: Inform the user that this moving time is not feasible,
because the time he/she chose is not in our working hours.
Ask the user to choose again]
workflow.summary: The workflow guides booking a moving service by first checking whether the move is within the same city. If it is, move details are collected and a fee is calculated; the customer can accept or decline the fee. If accepted, the customer selects a preferred time, which is either confirmed if feasible or the customer is asked to choose another time. If the move is not within the same city, the customer is informed that only same-city moves are offered and is asked whether they will modify their request; declining to change or declining the fee ends the process. The flow finishes with either a scheduled move or a notification that the request cannot be met.

apis.api_description: Eligibility inquiries for property claim

is_wheel.description: Whether the property is covered by insurance, enumerated type, [not in, in]

apis.api_description: Judge whether the property compensation audit is passed

thing_greel.description: Whether the user's property is damaged or lost, enumerated type, [damaged,lost]

is_passing.description: Audit passed or not, enumeration type, [passed, failed]

is_amount.description: Specific compensation amount, value + yuan, such as "300 yuan"

is_reason.description: Reasons why the audit failed, e.g. "Incorrect information submitted"

workflow.text: The process begins with a property claim where the initial step involves calling an API to determine if the property's insurance is still valid by checking if it's past its expiration date. This involves asking the user for details about the damaged or lost property and using the verifyInsurance function to check validity. If the insurance is invalid, the user is informed that compensation cannot be provided. If it's valid, it's then checked whether the damaged or lost property falls under the insurance coverage. If the property is covered, another API is called to decide if the audit for compensation passes. If the audit passes, the user is informed about the compensation amount, which will be delivered in three days. If the audit does not pass, the user is asked if they wish to readjust their claim. If readjustment is needed, the process loops back to the initial API call; if not, the user is apologized to for the inconvenience. On the other hand, if the property is not covered by insurance, the user is informed that the property is not eligible for compensation.
workflow.code:
-> Start
    -> Call API to determine whether the property is on the expiration date.
        Ask the user for the corresponding type and name of damaged and lost property,
        Call verifyInsurance, and determine if the property insurance is valid based on the returned is_date.
        -> Insurance invalid
            -> Inform the user that the insurance is not valid and compensation cannot be provided.
            -> END
        -> Insurance valid
            -> Judge whether the damaged and lost property is in the insurance coverage or not based on the returned is_wheel.
                -> Insurance in coverage
                    -> Call API to decide whether the audit passed or not.
                        Call submitClaimForm to perform a compensation audit,
                        Judge whether the audit is passed based on the returned is_passing.
                        -> Audit is passed
                            -> Inform the user that the audit has passed.
                                Tell the user of the amount of compensation based on the returned is_amount,
                                and the compensation will arrive in three days.
                            -> END
                        -> Audit is not passed
                            -> Ask if the claim needs to be readjusted.
                                Let the user know why the audit failed based on the returned is_reason,
                                and ask if the claim needs to be readjusted.
                                -> Needed
                                    -> [Go back to "Call API to determine whether the property is on the expiration date."]
                                -> Not needed
                                    -> Apologize to the user
                                    -> END
                -> Insurance not in coverage

workflow.summary: The workflow starts by collecting details about the damaged or lost property and calling an API to verify whether the policy is still active. If the insurance is expired, the user is told they are not eligible for compensation. If the policy is active, the system checks whether the item is covered; non-covered items are rejected. For covered items an audit API determines eligibility for payout: a passing audit leads to notification of the compensation amount and delivery in three days; a failing audit prompts the user to choose whether to readjust the claim, which, if chosen, restarts the process, otherwise the user is apologized to.

workflow.text: The flowchart describes a gas maintenance process starting with an inquiry about the maintenance location. If the maintenance is needed within the homeowner's meter area, it's considered the user's responsibility, and they are informed about self-maintenance options including doing it themselves, choosing third-party maintenance, or requesting the company's services. If the user opts for the company's maintenance, 'ContactMaster' is used to arrange a technician visit, while for third-party maintenance, the user is advised to independently find a technician, followed by a company inspection after seven days. In case the user is unavailable for the inspection, a preferred day for the maintenance check is scheduled. If the maintenance is needed outside and including the homeowner's meter area, it is the company's responsibility, and a technician is sent directly. This process ensures clarity on responsibility and options for gas maintenance for both within and outside the homeowner’s meter area.
workflow.code:
Start
  |--> Gas Maintenance
        |--> Inquire about the maintenance location
              |--> IF Within Homeowner Meter
                    |--> Inform the user of the self-maintenance option
                          |--> IF Request our maintenance
                                |--> Request a technician for home service
                          |--> ELSE IF Request third party maintenance
                                |--> User to contact independently
                                      |--> IF Available
                                            |--> Tell the user we will perform the inspection on the 7th business day.
                                      |--> ELSE
                                            |--> Confirm visit timing.
              |--> ELSE IF Outside of Homeowner Meter
                    |--> Request a technician for home service

workflow.summary: The workflow decides whether gas maintenance is inside or outside the homeowner’s meter area to assign responsibility. If it’s inside the meter area, the homeowner is responsible and may self-maintain, hire a third party, or request the company (which can schedule via ContactMaster); third-party work is followed by a company inspection after seven days (or a scheduled check if the homeowner is unavailable). If it’s outside (including the meter area), the company is responsible and dispatches a technician. The process clarifies responsibility and scheduling options.

workflow.text:
The flowchart outlines a process for handling gas service inquiries, which includes two main paths: gas fee inquiry and gas bill payment. Initially, the process starts with a gas fee inquiry where the system checks gas bills by calling the "lookMeter" function to query the gas cost. If the query is successful (i.e., "is_success" returns true), the system then informs the user about their remaining balance and asks if they need a detailed list of expenses. If the user requests a specific list, the system inquires which months are needed and provides a detailed expense list. Alternatively, if the user doesn't need a detailed list, the process ends with a thank you message.

For gas bill payments, the system obtains a payment link by calling the "getPayLink" function and requesting user information. If the acquisition is successful, the system checks if the user has already paid. If the payment has been made, it suggests checking whether the gas balance has been updated; if not, it instructs the user to complete the payment within 10 minutes. Should the query for either gas fee inquiry or payment link acquisition fail (due to incorrect user information, for example), the user is prompted to re-enter their information. This concise description encapsulates the process's efficiency in handling user inquiries and payments related to gas services.
workflow.code:
start: Start
    if (Gas fee inquiry) then (WT001)
    else (Gas bill payment) then (WT004)

WT001: Subgoal: check gas bills
    Description: Call lookMeter to query the gas cost.
    If the returned is_success is true, the query is successful.
        if (Successful query) then (WT002)
        else (Unsuccessful query) then (WT007)

WT002: Subgoal: Inform gas information to the user
    Description: Tell the user the money left and ask 
    if the user needs a more specific list of expenses based on returned expense_residual.
        if (Need specific list) then (WT003)
        else (Do not need specific list) then (WT006)

WT003: Subgoal: tell the list of expenses
    Description: Inquire what months of the list the user needs, 
    and inform the list of expenses based on returned expense_dict.

WT004: Subgoal: Get the payment link
    Description: Call getPayLink and ask for the user's information.
    If the returned is_success is true, the acquisition is successful.
    Provide the user with the payment link based on the returned pay_link.
        if (Acquisition is successful) then (WT005)
        else (Acquisition is unsuccessful) then (WT007)

WT005: Subgoal: Check whether the user has paid
    Description: Ask if the user has already paid.
    If so, it is recommended to check whether the gas balance has been received.
    If not, inform the user to pay within 10 minutes.

WT006: Thanks for the call, and goodbye to the user

WT007: Subgoal: ask the user to re-enter the information
    Description: The user's information is incorrect, need to enter again.

workflow.summary: The workflow manages gas service requests through two main paths: checking gas fees and handling bill payments. For fee inquiries it retrieves the user’s balance, offers a detailed expense list if requested, and finishes with a thank-you when no further detail is needed. For payments it generates a payment link, verifies whether payment has been made, and either confirms balance updates or prompts the user to complete payment within a short window. If any lookup or link generation fails (for example due to incorrect user information), the user is asked to re-enter their details.

workflow.text: The process starts with receiving feedback about a gas outage, followed by confirming the user's account information by calling the 'lookMeter' function to query the user's gas charge status. If the query is unsuccessful (is_success is false), the user is asked to re-enter their information. Once the query is successful, the system checks if the user has a sufficient balance. If the balance is sufficient, it then checks for any announcements. If there is an announcement, the user is informed about it and advised to use non-gas-dependent equipment temporarily. If there is no announcement, the system checks if gas is available in the surrounding area. If gas is available, it suggests a possible device malfunction and the need for repair. If gas is not available, it speculates possible reasons for the outage, such as maintenance or a broken main meter, and advises contacting the property management. If the initial check reveals an insufficient balance, the user is informed that they need to pay their bill to resolve the gas outage issue. This entire process ensures efficient troubleshooting based on the user's account status, balance, and external factors affecting gas supply.
workflow.code:
start: Start
  -> confirm_user_info

confirm_user_info: Subgoal: Confirm the user's account information
  Description: Call lookMeter to query the user's gas charge, determine whether the returned is_success is true. If it is false, tell the user to re-enter the information.
  -> query_successful, confirm_user_info

query_successful: Subgoal: Judge whether there is balance or not
  Description: Determine if the balance is sufficient based on the returned expense_residual.
  -> balance_sufficient, balance_insufficient

balance_sufficient: Subgoal: Decide if there is announcement
  Description: Judge if there is a notice based on the returned announcement.
  -> has_announcement, no_announcement

has_announcement: Subgoal: Notify the user announcement information
  Description: Inform the user of the announcement information based on the returned announcement. Tell the user that it is normal to be without gas temporarily, and advise using equipment that doesn't require gas.
  -> END

no_announcement: Inquire if there is gas around?
  -> gas_available, gas_unavailable

gas_available: Subgoal: Tell that there is a failure
  Description: Inform that the device may be malfunctioning, let someone get it repaired.
  -> END

gas_unavailable: Subgoal: speculate the possibility of no gas
  Description: Tell the user that everything is displayed as normal, only there is no gas at the user's home. Possible reasons for no gas can be speculated, like sudden maintenance or the main meter being broken. The user can contact the property to solve the problem.
  -> END

balance_insufficient: Subgoal: Let the user know the balance is insufficient
  Description: Through inquiries, the reason for no gas is insufficient balance. The user needs to pay the bill in time.
  -> END

workflow.summary: The workflow begins when a user reports a gas outage and the system verifies their account by calling the 'lookMeter' function. If verification fails, the user is asked to re-enter their information. If successful, the system checks the account balance: an insufficient balance prompts a payment request, while a sufficient balance leads to checking for service announcements. If there is an announcement, the user is informed and advised to use non-gas-dependent equipment temporarily; if not, the system checks gas availability in the area and either suggests a possible appliance fault (if gas is available) or advises contacting property management due to likely external causes such as maintenance or a broken main meter.

workflow.text: The process begins when there is a need to change a workstation. First, the system asks for the user's identity by calling the getUserInfo function and checks if the response (back_code) matches the correct identity. If the identity is correct, it then checks if the user has already determined a workstation. If the identity is incorrect, the system apologizes and rejects the request for a workstation change. For users with a defined workstation, the system verifies it by calling verificationStation. If the verification returns true, the system proceeds to fill out an application form and informs the user of the success or failure of the application based on the is_success response. A successful application results in the user being told that the workstation will change the next day, while an unsuccessful one prompts a notification of failure. If the workstation is undefined or the verification returns false, the system either provides feasible workstation options by calling recommendedStation or asks the user to re-select a workstation. Users can then decide to continue with the change or not. If they decide not to change the workstation, the process ends with a goodbye to the user. If they continue, the process loops back to verifying the new or provided workstation.

Description: Confirm whether the user has already determined the workstation?]

we need to reject the user's request for a workstation change.]

Description: Call verificationStation to verify the workstation
and determine whether it is true or false based on the returned feasible.]

Description: Call recommendedStation to get the workstations that can be provided to the user 
and provide the workstation number to the user based on the returned station_object.]

Description: The user doesn't change the workstation, we have to say goodbye to the user.]

Description: call applicationForm, 
inform the user whether the application was successful or not 
based on the returned is_success.]

the workstation will be changed tomorrow]
FF004--Unsuccessful-->FF007[Inform the user that the application was not successful]
FF001--False-->FF005[Current goal: Re-select the workstation
Description: The workstation is unavailable and we need to ask the user to re-select it.
The user can either select a new one or ask us to provide one.]
workflow.summary: When a workstation change is requested, the system first verifies the user’s identity. If the identity is invalid the request is rejected; if valid, the system checks whether a workstation is already defined. For a defined workstation it verifies the station and, if verification succeeds, submits an application and notifies the user of success (change takes effect next day) or failure. If the workstation is undefined or verification fails, the system offers recommended options or asks the user to reselect; the user may cancel (ending the process) or continue, in which case the process returns to verification.

workflow.text: The flowchart describes a process beginning with a start point where a user is requested to change their workstation. It progresses to asking the user for their identity, where the system uses getUserInfo to verify the user's identity. If the identity is correct, the system proceeds to obtain application results via obtainApplicationResults, checking if the application is passed or not. If the application is approved, the user is asked if they want to proceed with changing the workstation. If the user decides against changing the workstation, they must provide reasons for this decision. Conversely, if the user wants to change the workstation, they are reminded to do so before a specified deadline, informed by the deskChange function. Should the application be rejected, the user is notified of the failure and the reason behind it, with an invitation to reapply. If at any point the user's identity cannot be correctly verified, the system informs the user of the mistaken identity and rejects the workstation change request. This process involves various parameters, such as "no_change_reason" for not changing the workstation and utilizes API information for operations like obtaining user identity and application results.
workflow.code:
start
  Request the user to change the workstation
  getUserInfo -> back_code
  
  if back_code == Correct identity
    obtainApplicationResults -> is_pass
    
    if is_pass == True
      Ask if the user wants to change the workstation
      if Wants to change
        deskChange -> replace_time
        Remind the user to change the workstation as soon as possible
        [END]
      else
        Collect reasons for not replacing
        [END]
    else
      Notify that the application failed
      [END]
      
  else
    Inform of mistaken identity
    [END]

workflow.summary: The workflow manages a user request to change workstations: it first verifies the user’s identity (getUserInfo) and rejects the request if verification fails. If identity is confirmed, the system checks the application outcome (obtainApplicationResults). Approved applications prompt the user to confirm whether to proceed; if they agree, they receive a deadline reminder (deskChange), and if they decline their reason is recorded (no_change_reason). Rejected applications notify the user of the failure and reason and invite them to reapply. API calls are used for identity and application status retrieval.

workflow.text: The process begins with initiating a survey where the first step is to confirm if the person on the call is Mr. Wang Zhenyan. If the answer is no, the caller apologizes for the wrong call and informs the person about the mistake. However, if the answer is yes, meaning the caller is indeed speaking with Mr. Wang, who is a regular customer of Mr. Rice, the next step is to ask Mr. Wang if he has time to participate in a satisfaction survey. If Mr. Wang is willing to participate, the survey progresses to inquire about his satisfaction with the service provided. Depending on his response, if he is satisfied, the caller thanks Mr. Wang for his high evaluation and assures the continuation of good service. Conversely, if Mr. Wang is unsatisfied, the caller pledges to improve the services and apologizes for any inconvenience. If Mr. Wang is unwilling to participate in the survey at the moment, the caller then inquires if he could indicate a more convenient time for him. If Mr. Wang can provide a suitable time, the caller takes note of this and informs him that a call will be made during that time slot. If he cannot provide a time, the caller simply apologizes and ends the call.
workflow.code:
-> START
    -> Is the caller Mr. Wang Zhenyan?
        -> YES:
            -> Does Mr. Wang have time for a survey?
                -> WILLING:
                    -> Is Mr. Wang satisfied with our service?
                        -> SATISFIED:
                            [Thank Mr. Wang for his high evaluation and assure him of maintaining good service.]
                        -> UNSATISFIED:
                            [Inform Mr. Wang that we will improve our service and apologize.]
                -> UNWILLING:
                    -> Can Mr. Wang inform us when he will be available?
                        -> CAN TELL:
                            [Ask for Mr. Wang's available time. Inform him we'll call back at a suitable time.]
                        -> CANNOT TELL:
                            [Apologize and say goodbye to Mr. Wang.]
        -> NO:
            [Apologize for the wrong call and inform the user about the mistake.]

workflow.summary: Call begins by confirming the recipient’s identity; if it’s the intended customer (Mr. Wang Zhenyan) the caller asks for permission to conduct a satisfaction survey. If the customer agrees, the caller records satisfaction feedback and responds with thanks if positive or an apology and promise to improve if negative. If the customer declines the survey, the caller asks for a more convenient callback time and schedules it if provided; otherwise the caller apologizes and ends the call. If the person reached is not the intended customer, the caller apologizes for the wrong number and ends the call.

workflow.text:
The process begins by confirming whether the callee is Mr. Wang Zhenyan. If the answer is no, the caller apologizes and explains it is a wrong call, and the flow ends. If the answer is yes, the caller (Mr. Rice) introduces a current promotion in which all dishes are 6% off, and asks whether Mr. Wang has time to come.

If Mr. Wang does not have time, he is informed that the promotion starts next Monday and ends next Sunday, and he is invited again to see whether that window works. If he still has no time, the caller apologizes and ends the conversation.

If Mr. Wang does have time—either immediately or after hearing the promotion window—the caller asks whether he needs an appointment. Choosing no appointment means he can queue on arrival to participate in the promotion. Choosing appointment leads to a choice of making the appointment now or later. If he prefers to make it later, he is reminded to contact the restaurant by the following Monday to arrange it.

If he chooses to make the appointment now, the caller collects the user’s ID number and name and calls the userReservation API. If the API returns success, the caller confirms the appointment with Mr. Wang. If the API returns failure, the caller explains that the appointment did not succeed—possibly due to errors in the ID number or name—and asks Mr. Wang to re-provide the ID and name so the reservation can be retried. This flow ensures the callee is correctly identified, confirms availability during the promotion window, and offers a streamlined appointment option that skips queuing for those who schedule in advance.
workflow.code:
start: Start
Take part in the promotion -> verify_callee_identity

verify_callee_identity: Current goal: Confirm callee identity
Description: Ask if the user is Mr. Wang Zhenyan.
Is the user Mr. Wang Zhenyan? -> yes -> inquire_availability
Is the user Mr. Wang Zhenyan? -> no -> wrong_call

wrong_call: Current goal: Inform that there is a wrong call
Description: Apologize to the user and explain it is a wrong call. End the flow.

inquire_availability: Current goal: Inquire if the user has time to participate in the promotion
Description: Inform that this is Mr. Rice. Recently there is a promotion where all dishes are 6% off. Ask if the user has time to come.
Have time to come? -> yes -> ask_need_appointment
Have time to come? -> no -> provide_promo_window

provide_promo_window: Current goal: Provide promotion window and re-invite
Description: Inform that the promotion starts next Monday and ends next Sunday. Ask again if the user has time to come over within that window.
Have time within the window? -> yes -> ask_need_appointment
Have time within the window? -> no -> apologize_end

apologize_end: Current goal: Say sorry to the user
Description: Apologize for the inconvenience and end the conversation.

ask_need_appointment: Current goal: Ask if the user needs to make an appointment
Description: Tell the user that making an appointment in advance will skip queuing for the promotion. Ask if an appointment is needed.
Need an appointment? -> yes -> choose_appointment_timing
Need an appointment? -> no -> inform_queue

inform_queue: Current goal: Inform queue-on-arrival participation
Description: Inform the user they can queue on arrival to participate in the promotion.

choose_appointment_timing: Current goal: Inquire about appointment timing
Description: Ask whether the user wants to make an appointment now or later.
Make an appointment now? -> yes -> call_userReservation
Make an appointment now? -> no -> appointment_later_notice

appointment_later_notice: Current goal: Remind to arrange appointment later
Description: Inform the user to contact the restaurant by the following Monday to arrange the appointment.

call_userReservation: Current goal: Call API to determine whether the appointment is successful
Description: Obtain the user’s ID number and name, and call userReservation. Determine success based on the returned is_reserce.
Appointment successful? -> yes -> appointment_success
Appointment successful? -> no -> appointment_failed

appointment_success: Current goal: Confirm appointment success
Description: Inform the user that the appointment has been successfully made.

appointment_failed: Current goal: Tell that the appointment failed and retry
Description: Inform the user the appointment did not succeed (possibly due to errors in the ID number or name). Ask the user to re-provide the ID number and name, then retry.
Re-provide ID and name? -> yes -> call_userReservation

workflow.summary: Caller verifies the callee is Mr. Wang; if not, the call ends. If he is, the caller presents a 6% off promotion and checks his availability during the promotion window. If unavailable, the caller offers the promotion dates and ends if he still cannot attend. If available, the caller asks about an appointment: no appointment means queuing on arrival; postpone appointment prompts the callee to call later by a deadline; making the appointment now requires collecting ID and name and calling a reservation API, confirming on success or retrying collection on failure. The flow ensures correct identity, confirms availability, and provides an appointment option to avoid queuing.

apis.api_description: Book a meeting and judge the feasibility

meeting_time.description: Meeting time, format: year + month + day + hour + minute, such as "January 27, 2044, 17:22"

guest_name.description: Guest name, an appellation is available

guest_contact.description: Guest contact information, either a 13-digit phone number such as "13812345678" or an e-mail address in the format of "XXX@email.com"

guest_ding_account.description: Guest DingTalk account, if there is an account, fill in to determine whether one can attend the meeting, usually letters + numbers. If not, fill in ""

whether_contact.description: Whether to contact, enumeration type, [true, false]

ignore_error.description: Ignore errors, enumeration type, [true, false], default is false

whether.description: Feasible or not, enumeration type, [true, false]

items.description: Guest name, an appellation is available

guest_contact.description: Guest contact information, either a 13-digit phone number such as "13812345678" or an e-mail address in the format of "XXX@email.com"

reason.description: Reason for failure, such as "time error", "number of people exceeds limit", if possible," "

join_link.description: Join a link. URL, for example, "ding.com/s/code=98b6c5d995b77e2f9e790616c88490b5". If not feasible, then ""

workflow.text: This flowchart outlines a process for managing meeting schedules and notifications. Initially, it starts with launching the meeting process where it checks if the meeting can be scheduled by asking the user for meeting details and calling a function named `scheduleMeeting`. If the meeting is feasible, the user is notified that the meeting is set, and a text message is sent. The user is then asked if they need a meeting link and whether they want a reminder. If a reminder is desired, the user specifies a contact time, and they are informed that a reminder will be sent in advance. If no reminder is needed, the user is encouraged to join the meeting on time. However, if the meeting cannot be scheduled, the user is informed why it's not possible and asked if they want to adjust the meeting details or force the meeting to start. Forcing the meeting to start calls `scheduleMeeting` again to set up the meeting forcibly. If a meeting link is not needed initially, one is provided for user access. The process is designed to ensure smooth communication and scheduling for meetings, accommodating user needs for reminders and meeting adjustments as necessary.
workflow.code:
start
    -> Launch the meeting
    -> Confirm the meeting feasibility
        -> inquire the user for meeting information based on scheduleMeeting
        -> call scheduleMeeting
        -> confirm if the meeting is feasible
    
    if (Meeting is available) then
        -> Notify the meeting is feasible
            -> tell the user that the meeting is feasible
            -> send a text message to make contact
            -> ask if the user needs a meeting link?
            
        if (Link needed) then
            -> Ask the user if the reminder is needed
                if (Yes) then
                    -> Collect parameters: contact_time
                    -> Notify the user that the reminder will be given in advance
                else (No need to inform)
                    -> The user is invited to participate in the meeting on time
                endif
        else (No link needed)
            -> Provide the user with an entry link according to the returned join_link
            -> Ask the user if the reminder is needed
                [same decision process as above]
        endif
        
    else (Meeting is unavailable)
        -> inform the user of reasons
            -> inform the user of the cause of failure
            -> notify the user who cannot attend the meeting
        -> Ask if the user wants to adjust the meeting content or force the meeting to start
            if (Start meeting forcibly) then
                -> Call scheduleMeeting, set up a meeting forcibly
                -> go back to "Notify the meeting is feasible"
            else (Adjust meeting content)
                -> go back to "Confirm the meeting feasibility"
            endif
    endif
end

flowchart TD

and confirm if the meeting is feasible based on the returned whether?]
LA001--Meeting is available-->LA002[Subgoal: Notify the meeting is feasible.

LA002--Link needed-->LA003[ Ask the user if the reminder is needed]

LA004-->LA005

LA006-->LA007[Ask if the user wants to adjust the meeting content. Or force the meeting to start?]

LA009-->LA003

The auxiliary parameter information in the workflow is as follows:

workflow.summary: This workflow manages meeting scheduling by attempting to set up a meeting via a scheduleMeeting function, notifying the user and sending a text when successful. It then asks whether the user needs a meeting link and whether they want a reminder—if a reminder is requested it collects a contact time and confirms advance notification; if not, it prompts the user to join on time. If the meeting cannot be scheduled it explains the reason and offers options to adjust details or force-start the meeting, which retries scheduling.

apis.api_description: Check meeting information

meeting_time.description: Meeting start time, year + month + day, default "February 8, 2046"

is_start.description: Whether the meeting has started, enumeration type, [started, not started]

is_quit.description: Whether the meeting can be canceled, enumeration type, [yes, no]

is_reason.description: Reasons why the meeting cannot be canceled, enumeration type, [mobile phone issues, network connection issues, can be canceled]

is_main.description: Whether the user is the host of the meeting, enumeration type, [yes, no]

workflow.text: The flowchart describes the process for canceling a DingTalk meeting. Initially, it checks if the meeting has started by calling `inspectionMeeting`. If the meeting has started, it then checks if the meeting can be canceled. If it cannot be canceled, it determines whether the issue is due to mobile phone problems or network issues. For mobile phone issues, it suggests the user try using a computer, explaining that compatibility or bugs in the mobile DingTalk app might prevent meeting cancellation. For network problems, it recommends checking the network connection or switching networks before attempting to cancel again. If the meeting hasn't started, it guides the user to cancel the meeting through the DingTalk home page. If cancellation is possible, it asks for confirmation from the user, highlighting that cancellation is irreversible. If the user hesitates, it suggests taking more time to decide. Upon confirmation, it checks if the user is the meeting host; if so, the host can cancel the meeting. If not, the user is advised to consult with the host about canceling the meeting. This process ensures that meetings are only canceled when appropriate and that users are aware of the consequences and technical requirements for cancellation.
workflow.code:
start: Start
    cancel_dingtalk_meeting -> confirm_meeting_status
    
confirm_meeting_status: Subgoal: confirm the meeting status.
    Description: call inspectionMeeting to check meetings, determine whether the meeting has started or not based on the returned is_start
    meeting_starts -> determine_cancel_meeting
    meeting_does_not_start -> guide_user_to_cancel
    
determine_cancel_meeting: Determine whether the meeting can be canceled based on the returned is_quit
    meeting_cannot_be_canceled -> find_out_reason
    meeting_can_be_canceled -> inform_cancellation_consequence
    
find_out_reason: Find out the reason why the meeting can't be canceled is mobile phone issues or network connection issues according to the returned is_reason
    mobile_phone_issues -> ask_user_to_use_computer
    network_connection_issues -> require_user_to_check_network
    
ask_user_to_use_computer: Subgoal: ask the user to use a computer.
    Description: inform the user that DingTalk on mobile phones may have some bugs or compatibility issues, which will lead to uncanceled meetings, and the user is invited to try to log in the account using the PC DingTalk and then cancel the meeting.
    
require_user_to_check_network: Subgoal: require the user to check the network
    Description: mention that the network connected with the user's device is unstable, which may result in the inability to cancel the meeting. And advise the user to try to connect to other networks or restart network devices. Then try to cancel the appointment again.
    
guide_user_to_cancel: Guide the user to open DingTalk to find the scheduled meeting on the home page, enter the meeting details interface and select Delete to cancel the meeting.
    
inform_cancellation_consequence: Inform that once a meeting is canceled, it cannot be changed. Ask if the user is sure to cancel the meeting
    user_does_not_confirm -> suggest_user_to_think
    user_confirms -> judge_user_identity
    
suggest_user_to_think: Suggest that the user can think carefully before replying
    
judge_user_identity: Judge whether the user's identity is the meeting host based on the returned is_main
    yes -> click_end_meeting
    no -> consult_host_for_ending_meeting
    
click_end_meeting: Click end meeting button to cancel the meeting
    
consult_host_for_ending_meeting: The user can ask the meeting host if he/she can end the meeting. If the host agrees, the meeting can be ended
workflow.flowchart:
：
flowchart TD
PN000(Start)--Cancel DingTalk meeting-->PN001>[Subgoal: confirm the meeting status.
Description: call inspectionMeeting to check meetings, determine whether the meeting has started or not based on the returned is_start]
PN001--Meeting starts-->PN002[Determine whether the meeting can be canceled based on the returned is_quit]
PN002--Meeting cannot be canceled-->PN003[Find out the reason why the meeting can't be canceled is mobile phone issues or network connection issues according to the returned is_reason]
PN003--Mobile phone issues-->PN004[Subgoal: ask the user to use a computer.
Description: inform the user that DingTalk on mobile phones may have some bugs or compatibility issues, which will lead to uncanceled meetings, and the user is invited to try to log in the account using the PC DingTalk and then cancel the meeting.]
PN003--Network connection issues-->PN005[Subgoal: require the user to check the network
Description: mention that the network connected with the user's device is unstable, which may result in the inability to cancel the meeting. And advise the user to try to connect to other networks or restart network devices. Then try to cancel the appointment again.]
PN001--Meeting does not start-->PN006[Guide the user to open DingTalk to find the scheduled meeting on the home page, enter the meeting details interface and select Delete to cancel the meeting.]
PN002--Meeting can be canceled-->PN007[Inform that once a meeting is canceled, it cannot be changed. Ask if the user is sure to cancel the meeting]
PN007--User does not confirm-->PN011[Suggest that the user can think carefully before replying]
PN007--User confirms-->PN008[Judge whether the user's identity is the meeting host based on the returned is_main]
PN008--Yes-->PN009[Click end meeting button to cancel the meeting]
PN008--NO-->PN010[The user can ask the meeting host if he/she can end the meeting. If the host agrees, the meeting can be ended]
workflow.summary: This flowchart outlines the steps to cancel a DingTalk meeting: first check whether the meeting has already started. If it hasn’t, guide the user to cancel from the DingTalk home page. If it has started, determine whether cancellation is possible; if not, diagnose whether the problem is due to the mobile app (suggest using a computer) or network issues (suggest checking or switching networks). If cancellation is possible, request confirmation (noting cancellation is irreversible); if the user confirms, verify whether they are the meeting host—hosts can cancel directly, non-hosts should consult the host. The process emphasizes appropriate authorization, user awareness of consequences, and basic troubleshooting for technical barriers.

apis.api_description: Provide flights based on the information given by the user

starting_point.description: Starting city, in the format: province (if any) + city + district/county. For example, "Wanzhou District, Chongqing"

end_point.description: Terminal airport, in the format: province (if any) + city + district/county. For example, "Pudong District, Shanghai"

estimated_time.description: Estimated time. The format is year + month + day + hour.  For example "12 o'clock on January 7, 2199"

airline_company.description: Restricted airlines user desired. Blank means no restriction.

items.description: Names of airline companies, such as "Singapore Airlines, Emirates, Qatar Airways, Delta Air Lines, United Airlines, British Airways"

plan_dict.description: Aviation information available. Null means not available

workflow.text: The process described in the flowchart starts with checking for flights. First, it inquires the user for their departure city and date, then calls the planeSearch function to confirm if flight information can be found based on the returned plan_dict. If no information is found, the user is informed that there are no available flights on the selected route and is asked to reselect. This loop continues until a suitable flight is found. Once a flight is identified, the user is notified, a list of found flights is displayed based on plan_dict, and the user is asked for their flight preference. If the user selects a preferred flight, they are then asked for the flight ID, and the flight price is provided based on the returned plan_price. If the user does not prefer any flights, they are asked if they want to continue searching. If they choose to continue, the process loops back to inquiring for departure city and date. If they choose not to continue, the process ends with a goodbye message, always welcoming the user to inquire in the future.
workflow.code:
start: Start
check_flights: Check flights
inquire_user_for_info: Inquire the user for departure city and date, call planeSearch, and confirm if flight information can be found based on the returned plan_dict
inform_no_flights: Inform the user that there are no available flights on the route and ask the user to reselect
notify_flight_found: Notify the user that a suitable flight can be found, display the list of flights found based on the returned plan_dict, and ask the user for preferred flights
inquire_flight_ID: Inquire the user for flight ID, and tell the user of the flight price based on the returned plan_price
ask_continue_search: Ask whether the user wants to continue searching?
say_goodbye: Say goodbye to the user. The user is always welcome to inquire in the future

start->check_flights->inquire_user_for_info

inquire_user_for_info->inform_no_flights->inquire_user_for_info

inquire_user_for_info->notify_flight_found

notify_flight_found->inquire_flight_ID

notify_flight_found->ask_continue_search

ask_continue_search(yes)->inquire_user_for_info

ask_continue_search(no)->say_goodbye

MO001-- Information unfound-->MO005[Inform the user that there are no available flights on the route and ask the user to reselect]
MO005--reselect-->MO001

display the list of flights found based on the returned plan_dict, and ask the user for preferred flights]

The user is always welcome to inquire in the future]
workflow.summary: The workflow prompts the user for a departure city and date, then searches for available flights. If no flights are found, the user is informed and asked to try again; this repeats until flights are found or the user opts to stop. When flights are found, a list is shown and the user is asked about preferences. If they choose a specific flight, they provide its ID and receive the price. If they don’t prefer any listed flights, they can choose to continue searching or end the session. The process ends with a goodbye and an invitation to inquire again later.

workflow.text: The process begins with the start of booking a flight, where the system inquires the user for the Flight ID. It then calls a function to check the availability of the flight and confirms if the flight is available. If the flight is available, the system will inform the user and then ask for the user's ID number and name to proceed with reserving the flight. It checks if the reservation is successful based on the feedback received. If the reservation succeeds, the user is informed about the success and provided with the booking details. The system then asks if the user wishes to book another flight. If the reservation fails, the user is notified about the failure and also asked if they want to try booking again. Should the flight initially inquired about be unavailable, the user is informed, and the system checks if they want to book a different flight. If the user decides to book again, whether after a failure, success, or upon finding out their initial choice is unavailable, the process loops back to asking for flight details. If at any point the user decides not to rebook, they are welcomed to contact again for future needs. This process ensures that the user is guided through each step of booking, with clear outcomes for every scenario, including successful booking, failed booking, or the flight being unavailable.
workflow.flowchart:
：
flowchart TD
SK000(Start)--Book a flight-->SK001>Inquire the user for the Flight ID,
call checkAvailability to confirm flight status,
and check flight availability based on the returned is_air]
SK001--Flight is available--> SK002>Tell the user that the flight is available.
Ask the user for ID number and name, call reserveFlight, and check if the reservation is successful based on the returned is_successful ]
SK002--Reservation succeeded-->SK003[Inform the user that the reservation succeeded, and notify the user of booking details based on other returned values of reserveFlight. 
Ask if the user wants to book again]
SK002--Reservation failed-->SK004[Notify the user that the reservation failed and ask if the user wants to book again]
SK004  & SK003--User books again-->SK002
SK004 & SK003--User does not rebook-->SK006[The user is welcome to contact again for future needs]
SK001--Flight is unavailable-->SK005[Inform the user that the flight is unavailable, and confirm if the user wants to book another flight]
SK005--User books another flight-->SK001
workflow.summary: The workflow guides a user through booking a flight: it asks for a Flight ID, checks availability, and if available collects the user’s ID and name to attempt a reservation. The system informs the user of success or failure (providing booking details on success), and after any outcome asks whether the user wants to book again; if so the process repeats, otherwise it closes with an invitation to return later.

apis.api_description: Send an express

person_phone.description: Sender's phone number, composed of numbers, e.g. "13023782323"

person_position.description: Return address, e.g. "Chongqing Museum of Natural History"

people_phones.description: Recipient phone number, consisting of numbers, such as "13902027623"

people_positions.description: Recipient address, such as "Chongqing Fenghuang Village Committee"

is_sending.description: Whether the goods can be shipped, enumeration type, [No, yes]

apis.api_description: Check the tracking number of the express

is_num.description: The tracking number of the express, such as "010324102335"

workflow.text: The process begins with the start of sending a courier, where the first step involves gathering necessary information from the user, including the sender's and recipient's names, telephone numbers, and addresses. This information is then used to determine if the shipment can proceed. If the mail cannot be sent due to incorrect information, the user is informed and given the option to either correct the information or cancel the shipment. If the user decides to cancel, they are bid farewell. Conversely, if the shipment meets the requirements, the user is asked to confirm the information, with a stern reminder that no changes can be made post-confirmation. Should the user choose not to modify the information, the process advances to providing the user with a tracking number and asking if they wish to continue with the shipping. If the answer is no, the process ends with a farewell to the user. However, if the user wishes to proceed or decides to change the information at any point when prompted, the flow loops back to the information gathering stage to reassess the possibility of shipping based on the updated details, ensuring the user is always informed and in control of the shipping process.
workflow.code:
Start:
    Send courier
    Current goal: Determine whether the shipment can be shipped
    Description: Ask the user for sender and recipient information, including the sender's name, telephone number, address and the recipient's name, telephone number and address.
    Call getPackageType to determine whether the mail can be sent based on the returned is_sending
    if (Mail cannot be sent) then goto Inform_user_incorrect_info
    if (Mail can be sent) then goto Ask_user_change_info

Inform_user_incorrect_info:
    Current goal: Inform the user of the incorrect information
    Description: Inform the user that the information provided is incorrect. 
    Ask the user whether to change the information or drop the shipment
    if (Drop the shipment) then goto Say_goodbye
    if (Change the information) then goto Determine_shipment

Ask_user_change_info:
    Current goal: Ask the user whether to change the information
    Description: Inform the user that the shipping requirements have been met.
    The user needs to confirm the sender information and recipient information.
    Once the information is established, it cannot be changed. 
    The user has to confirm if he/she wants to change the information
    if (Do not change information) then goto Inform_user_tracking_number
    if (Change the information) then goto Determine_shipment

Inform_user_tracking_number:
    Current goal: Inform the user of the tracking number
    Description: Call sendCourier and tell the user the logistics number based on the returned is_num.
    Confirm if they want to continue sending
    if (NO) then goto Say_goodbye
    if (Yes) then goto Determine_shipment

Say_goodbye:
    Say goodbye to the user
    End

Determine_shipment:
    goto Start
workflow.flowchart:
：
flowchart TD
WW000(Start)--Send courier-->WW001>Current goal: Determine whether the shipment can be shipped

If information is invalid the user can correct it or cancel; if valid the user must confirm (no post-confirmation changes), receive a tracking number, and choose whether to continue. workflow.text: The flowchart describes a customer service process for handling express delivery inquiries. The process begins with asking the user for their order number to look up their shipment details. If the order is not found, the user is prompted to re-provide the order number, possibly due to a mistake in the initial entry. Once the order is found, the user is informed about the status of their delivery. If the item has not been delivered, the user can choose to either urge the logistics for faster delivery or check the current location of their order. If the item has been delivered, the user is asked whether they have received it. If they haven't, they're advised to check the nearby Cainiao Station for pickup. If the delivery has been received, the user's satisfaction with the express service is queried. Unsatisfied users are reassured that efforts will be improved for future satisfaction, while satisfied users are thanked for their positive feedback. This process ensures efficient tracking and resolution of delivery inquiries, enhancing customer satisfaction with the express service.
workflow.code:
-> START
    -> QUERY EXPRESS INFORMATION
        : Ask the user for the order number to query
        -> CALL getFullShipmentDetails
            IF Order is not found
                : Tell the user that the order cannot be found. The reason may be that the order number is wrong. The order number needs to be re-provided.
                -> ASK FOR ORDER NUMBER AGAIN
            ELSE IF Order is found
                : Inform the user that the corresponding order information has been successfully found. Tell the user the order information table based on the returned ticket_forms
                IF Item was not delivered
                    : Ask if the user wants to urge logistics or to check the current location of the order
                    IF Rush logistics
                        : Let the user know that we will contact the Courier immediately, and strive for faster delivery
                    ELSE IF View the current location of the order
                        : Tell the user the current position of the order based on the returned is_position
                ELSE IF Item was delivered
                    : Inform the user that the express has been delivered. Ask if he/she has received the delivery.
                    IF Have not received
                        : The user is advised to go to the nearby Cainiao Station to pick up the delivery
                    ELSE IF Received
                        : Ask if the user is satisfied with our express service
                        IF Unsatisfied
                            : Explain to the user that we will redouble our efforts in the future and strive to satisfy them next time
                        ELSE IF Satisfied
                            : Thanks for the user's high comments
